def plot_distribution(feat):
    df1 = pd.DataFrame(round(df_2020.groupby(feat)['salary_in_usd'].mean(),2)).reset_index()
    df2 = pd.DataFrame(round(df_2021.groupby(feat)['salary_in_usd'].mean(),2)).reset_index()
    df3 = pd.merge(left=df1,right=df2, on=feat, suffixes=['_2020', '_2021'])
    df4 = df3.dropna()
    plt.figure(figsize=(15,6))
    plt.subplot(1,2,1)
    sns.barplot(x=df4['salary_in_usd_2021'], y=df4[feat], order=df4.sort_values('salary_in_usd_2021', ascending=False)[feat], **{'edgecolor':'black', 'palette':'coolwarm'})
    plt.xlabel("Salary (in USD) for 2021", fontsize=13, labelpad=10)
    plt.ylabel('')
    plt.xticks(rotation=45)

    plt.subplot(1,2,2)
    sns.barplot(x=df4['salary_in_usd_2020'], y=df4[feat], order=df4.sort_values('salary_in_usd_2020', ascending=False)[feat], **{'edgecolor':'black', 'palette':'coolwarm'}, alpha=0.7)
    plt.xlabel("Salary (in USD) for 2020", fontsize=13, labelpad=10)
    plt.ylabel('')
    plt.xticks(rotation=45)
    name = feat.split('_')[0].title() + " " + feat.split('_')[1].title()
    plt.suptitle(f'Average Salaries across various "{name}"', fontsize=16)
    plt.tight_layout()

def plot_change(feat):
    df1 = pd.DataFrame(round(df_2020.groupby(feat)['salary_in_usd'].mean(),2)).reset_index()
    df2 = pd.DataFrame(round(df_2021.groupby(feat)['salary_in_usd'].mean(),2)).reset_index()
    df3 = pd.merge(left=df1,right=df2, on=feat, suffixes=['_2020', '_2021'])
    df4 = df3.dropna()
    df4['Change_percent'] = np.round(((df4['salary_in_usd_2021']/df4['salary_in_usd_2020'])-1)*100, 2)
    plt.figure(figsize=(15,6))
    sns.barplot(x=df4['Change_percent'], y=df4[feat], order=df4.sort_values('Change_percent', ascending=False)[feat], **{'edgecolor':'black', 'palette':'coolwarm'})
    plt.xlabel("% Change in salary", fontsize=13, labelpad=10)
    plt.ylabel('')
    name = feat.split('_')[0].title() + " " + feat.split('_')[1].title()
    plt.title(f"% Change in average salaries for various {name}s", fontsize=16)
    plt.show()

>For the period from 2020 to 2021, a strong growth in the mean salaries of Data science professionals could be observed. During the same period, remote jobs have been preferred more over
regular jobs. As far as salaries are concerned, there has been a substantial increase in the number of professionals bagging salaries upto 200,000 USD.


>In terms of average salaries with respect to Job titles for the year 2021, ML Engineer, Principal Data Scientist and Machine Learning Infrastructure Engineer bagged the top 3 positions.
ML Engineer's average salary has increased by 16 times over the period from 2020 to 2021 followed by Machine Learning Infrastructure Engineer by 3 times. 
This indicates a huge increasing importance in data engineering skills in data science industry. On the contrary, Big Data Engineer, Research Scientist and Computer Vision Engineer 
came at the bottom 3 places in terms of change in average salary for the period from 2020 to 2021.


>Coming to various experience levels, only Executive level professionals had an increase in their average salary and that too by about 14%. All other professionals at other excperience levels
had a decrease in their salary with entry level professionals bearing more than 10% decrease in their average take home pay.


>With respect to average salaries based on employee residence for the year 2021, Data science professionals from US, Russia and Japan earned the top 3 position.
Data science professionals from Nigeria (400%), Italy (300%) and Russia (over 150%) experienced the highest change in their mean salaries from 2020 to 2021.
Though Indian data science professionals bagged the 4th position (150%) in terms of increase in the average salaries based on employee residence, 
Data science professionals from India and other developing countries are hugely underpaid compared to US, Russia and Japan.
Data science professionals in Mexico, Poland and Spain experienced huge decrease in average salaries over the period from 2020 to 2021 with professionals from Mexico 
experiencing more than 90% decrease in their salaries.


>Data science professionals working on contract and part-time basis received an increase in salary with contract workers grabbing more than 1.5 times previous year salary on average.
Though not much change could be observed for full-time employees, freelancers have taken a huge hit in their average salaries that decreased by almost 75%.


>Data science professionals working in the US bagged top position with respect to their average salaries for 2021 overtaking Japan.
When companies in Nigeria (400%), Canada (over 100%) and India (over 100%) gave the top 3 hike in their employees average pay, those at Mexico followed by Austria and Great Britain 
had to cut a huge portion of their employees average salaries.


>Data science professionals working in mid sized companies have taken a hit in their mean salaries. Whereas, those in small and large companies have recieved a hike.
Professionals working remotely had an increase in their average salary for 2020 and 2021 compared to professionals who does less than 20% of their work remotely. 
Therefore, its better to have a full time job along with part time remote work compared to completely relying on remote work.


>Freshers and entry level professionals in Data science have opted for full time employment only which is the best option for a data science fresher in India 
as well as for any fresher around the world.


>Again, for an Indian data scientist, irrespective of their experience level, a full time employment is the best option.
For an Indian fresher data science aspirant, becoming a Data Scientist would be the best choice based on salary. But, being a data engineer is not bad either.


>Top 3 posts are ofcourse attainable only for an experienced professional. 
Hence for freshers, it would be best to pursue becoming a Data Analyst followed by Computer Vision Software Engineer and Machine Learning Engineer.


>For an executive level Indian data science professional, highest pay is obtained for the role of BI Data Analyst.
For a senior level Indian data science professional, highest pay is obtained for the role of Data Science Manager.
For an mid level Indian data science professional, highest pay is obtained for the role of Big Data Engineer closely followed by Lead Data Analyst and Data Scientist.


>Having a full time job along with remote work is the best option for an Indian data science fresher. 
Leaving aside the salary, it is still the best option for a fresher as the office exposure and experience gained from seniors and peers are priceless.
Fully remote work pays the most for a fresher data science professional.
For executive level professionals, remote work pays the most. But when coming to mid level professionals, non-remote work pays the most. 
For senior level professionals as well, remote work doesn't pay well compared to non-remote work options.


>China with an annual pay of 75lakhs INR is the best option for a fresher data scientist followed by US and Great Britain.
For an Indian data science fresher, India is indeed the best option to start the career in data science.
For executive level Indian data science professional, US is the best location in terms of salary.
For senior level Indian data science professionals, India followed by US are the best options.
For mid level Indian data science professionals, India is the best location for the job.


>For an Indian data science fresher, a mid level company pays the most. But when it comes to any fresher across the world, a small company is the best choice.
For all levels of experience except entry level professionals, a large company pays the most salary and hence the best option.

source.d3d61cf7:
### work_year
The year during which the salary was paid. There are two types of work year values:  
**2020**  : Year with a definitive amount from the past  
**2021e** : Year with an estimated amount (e.g. current year)

### experience_level
The experience level in the job during the year with the following possible values:  
**EN**  : Entry-level / Junior  
**MI**  : Mid-level / Intermediate  
**SE**  : Senior-level / Expert  
**EX**  : Executive-level / Director

### employment_type
The type of employement for the role:  
**PT**  : Part-time  
**FT**  : Full-time  
**CT**  : Contract  
**FL**  : Freelance  

### job_title
The role worked in during the year.  

### salary
The total gross salary amount paid.  

### salary_currency
The currency of the salary paid as an ISO 4217 currency code.  

### salaryinusd
The salary in USD (FX rate divided by avg. USD rate for the respective year via fxdata.foorilla.com).  

### employee_residence
Employee's primary country of residence in during the work year as an ISO 3166 country code.  

### remote_ratio
The overall amount of work done remotely, possible values are as follows:  
**0**    : No remote work (less than 20%)  
**50**   : Partially remote  
**100**  : Fully remote (more than 80%)  

### company_location
The country of the employer's main office or contracting branch as an ISO 3166 country code.  
  
### company_size
The average number of people that worked for the company during the year:  
**S**  : less than 50 employees (small)  
**M**  : 50 to 250 employees (medium)  
**L**  : more than 250 employees (large)
